Elon Musk on building his first startup Zip2

In 1995, when he was just 23 years old, Elon dropped out of Stanfordâ€™s PhD program in physics to start Zip2 with his brother Kimbal Musk.

Elon personally wrote the first national maps, directions, yellow pages and white pages on the Internet that summer in C with a little C++.

In this CBS interview, a 27 year old Elon describes living in a $200/month office with a leaky roof:

â€œWe found that an office was actually cheaper than apartment in Silicon Valley and we got this dinky little office that had a leaky roof. It was just the nastiest place you could imagine. I lived in it too and showered at the YMCA. This lasted for about three or four months, and the reason we chose this office â€” in addition to it being really cheap â€” was that there was an internet service provider on the floor below. So we were able to get really cheap internet access by drilling a hole in the floor and connecting to their server directly.â€

In February 1999 â€” less than a year after this interview â€” Compaq would purchase Zip2 for $307 million in cash.

The interviewer also asks Elon what he thinks the future of the Internet will be, to which Elon responds:

â€œI think the internet is the superset of all media. It is the be all and end all of media. One will see print, broadcast, radio â€” essentially all media â€” folding into the internet. What the internet amounts to is itâ€™s the first two-way communication medium that is intelligent. It allows consumers to choose what they want to see, when they want to see it.â€

result.text:
I'm Boris and I created Claude Code. Lots of people have asked how I use Claude Code, so I wanted to show off my setup a bit.

My setup might be surprisingly vanilla! Claude Code works great out of the box, so I personally don't customize it much. There is no one correct way to use Claude Code: we intentionally build it in a way that you can use it, customize it, and hack it however you like. Each person on the Claude Code team uses it very differently.

So, here goes.

ðŸš¨ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ FRAUD INVESTIGATION SPREADS TO WASHINGTON STATE: DAYCARE WITH 7 KIDS RECEIVED $81,000 IN ONE MONTH

Minnesota. Ohio. Now Washington.

Citizen journalist Cam Higby uncovered what appears to be the same playbook operating in Washington State.

Amira Child Care LLC, owned by Ahmed Amira and listed as Somali-speaking, donated $1,000 cash in 2021 to Shukri Olow, a Somali-born candidate for King County Council and Washington State House.

That donation triggered a Public Disclosure Commission investigation.

PDC Case #96266 alleged Olow's campaign accepted contributions exceeding statutory limits. 

The case was closed with a "reminder" after Olow refunded the over-limit portions. 

The PDC noted she was a "first-time candidate." 

The timing and amount, $1,000 in 2021, align with the reported violations.

Now follow the money:

2021-2023: Ahmed Amira Abdi received $383,000 in grants from the Department of Children, Youth and Families.

2023-2025: Amira Child Care LLC received $363,000.

July-November 2025 alone: $355,000. 

December not yet reported.

The math doesn't add up.

Licensed capacity: 12 children. 

Currently enrolled: 7 children.

September 2025 payment: $81,263. 

That's $11,600 per child for one month.

Higby's conclusion: 

"What it appears to be is a child care organization owned by a Somali person donating to Somali political candidates with taxpayer dollars."

Three states. Same pattern. Massive subsidies. 

How deep does this go?

Source: @camhigby / Washington PDC Case #96266

In the novel Scoundrel in the Thick,Thomas Scoundrel and his best friend Diego de San MartÃ­n are accompanied in their search for Diegoâ€™s fiancÃ© Rosalilia by Itzcoatl, a descendant of Aztec nobility who helped raise Diego from childhood. Itzcoatl is a warrior with a philosopherâ€™s heart who lives by a strict code of honor and ultimately lays down his life to save Diego and protect a village from a vicious raiding party. The excerpt below is from Chapter 43, and describes Diegoâ€™s visit to his cherished friendâ€™s grave:
                                       Itzcoatl
The next evening a cooling wind blew down from the neighboring mountains and across Manzanita Flats. Diego had been patched up, fed, and bathed. The town carpenter built a simple pine coffin for Itzcoatl, and the entire population of a grateful town gathered at the cemetery to listen to the preacher say a few words over the grave. Diego would keep Itzcoatlâ€™s rifle and dagger, but he asked Karlsson to sell the horse and saddle and use the money to purchase materials for the new school the town was building.

After dinner, Diego limped up to the cemetery. He carried a folding chair, a bottle of mezcal, and a blue glass. When the sun dipped below the western mountains, and the stars carpeted the ink-black heavens, he poured a glass of mezcal and settled onto the chair beside Itzcoatlâ€™s grave.

First Xipil, and now his father, Diego thought. Both killed in the effort to find Rosalilia. He knew better than to question whether his friendsâ€™ deaths were worth it. Since he was a boy, Itzcoatl had hammered home the importance of living with honor. It is better to die for something, he would say, than to live for nothing. Itzcoatl died, as he had lived, by that credo.

Diego finished his drink and then poured the rest of the bottle out onto the rocky grave. He stood with his hands on the wooden chair for support, looked up into the glittering night sky, and recited the Aztec prayer that Itzcoatl had spoken every night since he was a child:

"Only for so short a while you have loaned us to each other because we take form in your act of drawing us, and we take life in your painting us, and we breathe in your singing us. But only for so short a while have you loaned us to each other. Because even a drawing cut in obsidian will fade, and the green crown feathers of the Quetzal bird will lose their color, and the sounds of the waterfall will die out in the dry season. So, we too, shall die because only for a short while have you loaned us to each other."

He leaned the empty bottle against the rough wooden cross the villagers had pounded into the hard dirt, turned, and walked away.

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) announced that the Trump administration is freezing federal child care funding to every single U.S. state after introducing a freeze on Minnesotaâ€™s program â€” in response to ongoing allegations and evidence of widespread fraud.

On Wednesday, HHS spokesperson Andrew Nixon told ABC News that states will receive the funds â€œonly when states prove they are being spent legitimately.â€ Future payments now require prior justification, receipts, or photo evidence to verify legitimate spending before funds are released.

The announcement is in response to a report released by independent journalist Nick Shirley last week. Shirley claimed to have exposed $110 million in fraud during his investigation, after going to several daycare centers in Minneapolis, collecting millions in state and federal funds, only to find the locations desolate.

Nixon told the outlet that funding recipients â€œnot suspected of fraudulent activityâ€ are being instructed to send their â€œadministrative dataâ€ to HHS for review. 

â€œItâ€™s the onus of the state to make sure that these funds, these federal dollars, taxpayer dollars, are being used for legitimate purposes,â€ he continued, noting that funding recipients â€œsuspected of fraudulent activityâ€ are obligated to provide the federal government with additional documentation such as â€œattendance records, licensing, inspection and monitoring reports, complaints and investigations.â€ 

Wednesdayâ€™s announcement follows HHS Deputy Secretary Jim Oâ€™Neillâ€™s Tuesday statement pausing all child care payments to the state of Minnesota.

Oâ€™Neill made the announcement in an X post, announcing three actions the department is taking to root out the â€œblatant fraud that appears to be rampant in Minnesota and across the country.â€ 

Explaining the changes, Oâ€™Neill stated that all Administration for Children & Families (ACF) payments â€œacross America will require a justification and a receipt or photo evidence before we send money to a state.â€ 

Oâ€™Neill went on to demand a comprehensive audit of the Minnesota-based daycare centers, including â€œattendance records, licenses, complaints, investigations, and inspections.â€ 

â€œWe have launched a dedicated fraud-reporting hotline and email address at https://t.co/skW0b4R4Ec Whether you are a parent, provider, or member of the general public, we want to hear from you,â€ he added. â€œWe have turned off the money spigot and we are funding the fraud.â€ 

Alongside additional guardrails placed by HHS, the fraud is being investigated by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the FBI, according to DHS Secretary Kristi Noem and FBI Director Kash Patel. 

â€œHomeland Security Investigations are on the ground in Minneapolis right now conducting a massive investigation on childcare and other rampant fraud,â€ Noem wrote in an X post on Monday.

â€œSo there is this tactical opportunity, which I think if you want to have a chance in the midterms and if you generally wanna have a chance to  level-set the country,  you must take this and run with it.â€

â€œAnd then separately, if as Friedberg says, it does die on the vine, it is the beginning of the end of the American Empire, unfortunately.â€

result.text:
Over the last week, SBA has reviewed thousands of potentially fraudulent pandemic-era PPP and EIDL loans approved in Minnesota. 

Today, our agency took action to suspend 6,900 Minnesota borrowers amid suspected fraudulent activity. In total, these borrowers were approved for 7,900 PPP and EIDL loans worth approximately $400M.

These individuals will be banned from all SBA loan programs, including disaster loans, going forward. We will also refer every case, where appropriate, to federal law enforcement for prosecution and repayment. 

After years, the American people will finally begin to see the criminals who stole from law-abiding taxpayers held accountable - and this is just the first state.
